STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
June 12, 2024
Shaun Christopher Culp
CALHOUN COUNTY DHHS
190 E MICHIGAN AVE,
BATTLE CREEK, MI, 49014-4005
RE: License#: CP130201006
Dear Shaun Christopher Culp:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 6/7/2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616)204-6992.
Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP130201006
Licensee Group Organization: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Designee: Demetrius LuJuan Starling
Chief Administrator: Shaun Christopher Culp
Name of Agency: CALHOUN COUNTY DHHS
Agency Address: 190 E MICHIGAN AVE
BATTLE CREEK, MI 49014-4005
Agency Telephone #: 2699661414
Original Issuance Date: 02/01/1992
Service Types: Certify foster homes for license, Supervise
Independent Living, Place children in foster
home

II. METHODS OF INSPECTION
A. Consultant
Date(s) of On-site Inspection: 6/3/2024
Total No. Of No. of
Records Records
Reviewed
Current licensed foster homes 53 3
Homes pending licensure 17 3
Foster homes closed since the last inspection 9 2
Foster homes borrowed since the last inspection 21 3

in foster care since last inspection 0 0

since last inspection 0 0
Children receiving direct foster care case management (placement in foster homes,
relative homes, CCI, hospital, etc.) 161 8
Children discharged from care during this period 125 8

Applicants approved for adoption since the last inspection N/A N/A

Open child adoption cases

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement
• (3) The agency shall document all the following
in the child's record before a change of
placement occurs:
• (f) Notification to the parents, referral
source, lawyer guardian ad litem, and
courts when applicable, of the change in
placement.
Two of eight open files of youth in foster care placements did not contain
documentation that all required notifications were made regarding a placement
change.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED (previously cited as FOM 722-08E)
Renewal 7/15/2022, CAP Approved 7/21/2022
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement
• (3) The agency shall document all the following
in the child's record before a change of
placement occurs:

• (g) Information about the child was
shared with the new placement,
consistent with the requirements of R
400.12417.
One of eight open files of youth in foster care placements did not contain
documentation that all required information, including medical authorization, was
provided to the new caregivers at placement changes.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
• (1) An agency's medical and dental care policy
must, include all the following:
• (c) A physical examination for each child
as follows, unless a greater frequency is
medically indicated:
• (i) A comprehensive medical
examination, including a
behavioral/mental health and
trauma screening, within 30
calendar days from the date the
child entered into an out-of-home
placement, regardless of the date
of the last physical examination.
Two of eight open files of youth in foster care placements did not contain
documentation that the initial medical exams were completed within 30 calendar
days of initial placement
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
• (1) An agency's medical and dental care policy
must, include all the following:
• (d) Current immunizations for each child
as required by section 5111 of the public
health code, 1978 PA 368, MCL
333.5111. All the following apply:
• (ii) A copy of a waiver addressed
to the department that is signed by
the parent stating immunizations

are not being administered due to
religious, medical, or other reasons
is sufficient documentation of
immunizations, unless the child is
a temporary court ward, a motion
is heard, and order is entered by
the circuit court for the child's case.
A waiver must be accompanied by
a certification by the local health
department that the parent or
parents received education on the
risks of not receiving the vaccines
being waived and the benefits of
vaccination to the individual and
the community as required by
section 5111 of the public health
code, 1978 PA 368, MCL
333.5111, and R 325.176(12).
One of eight open files of youth in foster care placements documented that the
youth's immunizations were overdue. The file did not contain a waiver completed
by the youth's parents.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
• (1) An agency's medical and dental care policy
must, include all the following:
• (e) A dental examination must be
completed within 3 months before entry
into foster care or an initial dental
examination must be completed not more
than 90 calendar days after entry into a
foster care out-of-home placement. A
child entering foster care under 1 year of
age must have an initial dental exam
within 3 months of his or her first birthday.
One of eight open files of youth in foster care placements documented that a
dental exam was not completed within 90 calendar days of initial placement.
CPA Rule 400.12421 Visitation and family time; in person contact

• (2) An agency social service worker shall visit
the foster child, and the foster parent, if
applicable, in the child's placement at least once
every month.
Two of eight open files of youth in foster care placements did not contain
documentation that the youth and caregivers were visited in the caregiver's home
every calendar month. One file was missing the visit in November and both files
were missing the visit in February 2024.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED (previously cited as R 400.12421(b))
Interim 6/12/2023, CAP Approval 7/6/2023
CPA Rule 400.12502 Program statement
• (2) An agency shall give a copy of the program
statement to a youth before placement in
independent living.
One of three open files of youth in Independent living placements did not contain
documentation that the Program Statement was provided to the youth prior to
placement in the program.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED (previously cite as R 400.12502)
Interim 6/12/2023, CAP Approval 7/6/2023
CPA Rule 400.12503 Policy and procedures
• (3) An agency shall provide a youth in
independent living with a copy of the agency's
policies and procedures required by this rule.
One of three open files of youth in Independent living placements did not contain
documentation that the Policies and Procedures were provided to the youth prior
to placement in the program.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED (previously cite as R 400.12503)
Interim 6/12/2023, CAP Approval 7/6/2023
CPA Rule 400.12505 Supervision

• (2) An agency shall provide the following
minimum supervision:
• (b) At monthly intervals, ensure that the
youth is complying with the terms of the
required by R 400.12510, continues to
reside in a safe and acceptable
environment, and is managing
expenditures.
Two of three open files of youth in Independent living placements did not
document that the worker observed and the youth's placement to determine
safety and suitability. One file was missing this for one month and the other for
two months.
CPA Rule 400.12507 Medical, dental and mental health care
• (1) An agency shall ensure that a youth in
independent living receives any needed medical,
dental, and mental health care as required in R
400.12413. Medical, dental, and mental health
care provided must be documented in the
youth's record.
One of three open files of youth in Independent living placements did not contain
documentation that the youth under the age of 18 received a periodic dental
examination timely.
CPA Rule 400.12510 Independent living agreement
• (1) There must be a mutual agreement between
the youth and the agency specifying all the
following:
• (a) The responsibilities of the agency and
the youth.
One of three open files of youth in independent living placements did not contain
an initial IL contract.

FOM 722-06B FAMILY TEAM MEETING
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as
outlined in the following tables:
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment Initial Case
Plan (ISP) - within 30 calendar days before the case
plan due date. Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30
calendar days before the case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30
calendar days before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/ Disruption At least three
business days prior to a planned change of placement
or no later than three business days after an unplanned
placement change.
Case Closure Within 30 calendar days before the case
closure date or one business day after unplanned court
ordered dismissal.
Documentation The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting
Report, is used to capture family demographics, FTM
logistical information, needs, strengths, action steps,
safety concerns and the safety plan, and any
recommendations made for the family during the FTM.
The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be completed for
every FTM.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in
MiSACWIS using the FTM hyperlink within 7 business
days of the FTM.
Four of eleven open youth files (8 foster care, 3 IL) did not contain documentation
that all FTM requirements were met. Three files were missing timely service plan
development FTMs for one service plan, two files were missing replacement
FTM’s for one placement change.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal 7/15/2022, CAP Approved 7/21/2022
Interim 6/12/2023, CAP Approval 7/6/2023

FOM 722-06H CASE CONTACTS
CONTACT WITH CHILDREN - GENERAL
REQUIREMENTS Quality Visits
Quality visits between the case manager and child
have been found to produce positive outcomes for
children in care. A quality visit is defined as one in
which the case manager: • Can meet with each child
individually, without the presence of other individuals,
to give the child an opportunity to ask questions as well
as discuss the current placement. • Views the child's
bedroom and sleeping arrangements. • Verifies safe
sleep environments and practices for infants under 12
months. • Assesses each child’s educational, medical,
dental, mental health, and other needs and takes
appropriate action or offers services in response to the
identified needs of each child. • Shows interest in the
child to build and establish rapport. • Shares and
explains the case plan, including the plan for parenting
time, visits with siblings and other relatives, and the
child's permanency plan, in a developmentally
appropriate way while allowing the child to ask
questions and express viewpoints.
One of eight open files of youth in foster care placements did not contain
documentation that quality visits were occurring in the foster home with the
caregivers and youth monthly. The narrative was lacking quality contact
information.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal 7/15/2022, CAP Approved 7/21/2022
FOM 722-08D TREATMENT PLANS - AGREEMENT AND
SIGNATURES
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must
obtain signatures from the following individuals, as
applicable:
• Caseworker
• Supervisor
• Second line supervisor, when siblings in care are
placed apart

• Parents who are a member of a participating
household.
• Youth ages 14 and older.
• Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated
court-ordered caregivers.
Parents/legal guardians, youth, and caregivers must
check yes or no for the following when signing the
treatment plan:
• I have participated in the development of the Case
Service Plan and the Parent Agency Treatment Plan.
• I agree with the Case Service Plan and Parent
Agency Treatment Plan.
• I have been provided a copy of the Case Service Plan
and Parent Agency Treatment Plan to review, and I will
have the opportunity to express my disagreement with
the Case Service Plan and Parent Agency Treatment
Plan when the information is presented to court.
Note: If a parent or youth is unavailable or refuses to
sign the treatment plan, the caseworker must identify,
and document actions needed to secure the parent’s
and/or youth’s participation in service planning and
compliance with the treatment plan.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all
applicable individuals and upload the signatures pages
into the electronic case record within 30 days of the
report date.
Two of eleven open youth files (8 foster care, 3 IL) did not contain all required
PATP signatures obtained timely.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal 7/15/2022, CAP Approved 7/21/2022
Interim 6/12/2023, CAP Approval 7/6/2023
FOM 801-03 MEDICAL PASSPORT
For children entering foster care, the initial medical
passport must be provided within two weeks of the
child's placement date to the following: • Foster care
provider. • Young adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC)
youth/young adult re-entering foster care. The actual
date the medical passport is provided must be

documented in the electronic case management
record. Note: Foster care provider includes foster
homes, shelter, adult foster home, fictive kin, relative
placements, detention, and residential facilities.
All medical information within the medical passport
must be current and updated at least quarterly to reflect
the child's current and complete health information.
Each caseworker who transfers a child's medical
passport to another caseworker must sign and date the
medical passport verifying that they have sought and
obtained the necessary information under law and
Michigan Department of Health and Human Services
(MDHHS) policy.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
• Participating legal parents if the child is a temporary
court ward. Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement.
At reunification. Subsequent medical passports are not
required after reunification. Non-offending parent,
subsequent medical passports are not required after
reunification.
• The child’s foster care provider at or prior to each
placement. Note: Non-offending parent with custody of
the child is not considered a foster parent placement.
• All medical and mental health professionals to whom
the child is newly referred to and accepted for
treatment or services prior to or at the first scheduled
appointment while the foster care case is open,
regardless of placement. Subsequent medical
passports are not required.
• Older youth/young adults: Upon initial independent
living placement (youth aged 16 and over). Upon
exiting the foster care system (young adults aged 18
and older)
Receipt of the medical passport by the above listed
parties is documented in the electronic case
management record by uploading the signed and dated
signature page into the Health Profile section.

Two of eleven open youth files (8 foster care, 3 IL) did not contain all Medical
Passports provided, updated and/or signed quarterly, as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal 7/15/2022, CAP Approved 7/21/2022
Interim 6/12/2023, CAP Approval 7/6/2023
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Rules require dental documentation be uploaded. When accepting transferred
cases, be sure all paperwork is in the record prior to accepting or continue to
request paperwork until received.
• Review case records for correct labelling and location of uploaded documents.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Reminder, when a case transfers in from another agency, a service plan which
addresses the transfer must be completed within 30 days. This also applies to IL
youth.
• Rules require social service worker visit the youth and caregiver in the
caregiver's home every calendar month, which differs from policy requirements.

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plan (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows. The CAP
was in response to the 6/12/2023 licensing interim inspection report. The CAP was
approved on 7/6/2023 and addressed 6 violations (3 licensing rules and 3 DHHS
policy.) The agency CAP was not effective in eliminating noncompliance as all
violations addressed in that CAP were repeated during this year's inspection. It is
noted; however, the CAP was effective in reducing the individual instances of non-
compliance related to medical passports. All other repeated violations remained
the same or slightly increased in the number of files in non-compliance. Nine
violations (8 rules, 1 DHHS policy) were established during this inspection which
were not established during the previous year. It is noted of the 15 overall
violations established during this inspection, 8 were located in 1 file, 6 were found
in 2 files, and 1 was located in 4 files. The agency corrective action plan must
evaluate and address the repeated non-compliances as well as the additional non-
compliances not previously established. The management team did identify that
the majority of violation were located within a case record previously managed by
a worker who is no longer with the agency. Prior to this employee's departure, the
employee was receiving disciplinary action for performance related concerns.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The chief administrator assessment was reviewed and discussed. The chief
administrator identified areas of non-compliance largely attributed to a high
number of new staff learning the rule & policy requirements as well as individual
staff performance issues resulting in disciplinary action.
Financial Overview
N/A
Staff Interviews
The staff interviewed reported feeling supported and assisted by leadership,
indicating they have helpful group chats, meetings, and other resources available
at all times. They report receiving policy and rule updates timely. They all talked
about control documents utilized to help keep them on track with due dates and
required task completion, which they find helpful. No concerns were noted by any
of the staff members.

Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency maintains sufficient office space and equipment to ensure delivery of
foster care, independent living, and certification services. Case files and physical
CHRI are stored securely in locked cabinets that cannot be accessed by
unauthorized personnel.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
June 11, 2024
_____________________________________
Holly Austin Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
June 12, 2024
_____________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
